> From: areider [mailto:areider@...] 

> Is it true that test method=
s must return void in order to be 
> considered a test method? 

Yes, but i=
f I were you I wouldn=92t just trust what some stranger like me
on the Inte=
rnet told you. If you really want to know the answer, look at
the source or=
 trace through test execution with a debugger. There's not
very much code t=
here so it wouldn't take more than 30 minutes to have
intimate knowledge of=
 the whole thing.

> It seems that if a value is returned from a 
> testXXX=
XX method, it is not included. 

Yes.

> Is there a hard reason why? (ie wo=
uld it break junit to allow test 
> methods which return values 

One reaso=
n not to do that is that supporting (utility, etc.) methods
might be interp=
reted as test methods. You'd have to make sure they never
start with 'test'=
.

> or is it just a convention to make the 
> introspection easier?)

Prob=
ably. The originators might have thought of some other reason as
well.

> 
=
> I would like to write test methods that I can reuse outside of junit, 
> =
where I would want to inspect the result of the test. Right now I'm 
> face=
d with writing the methods twice.

Write those methods as you'd like to and=
 then just 'publish' them for
JUnit's consumption with JUnit style test met=
hods that just wrapper/call
them.
